awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Elements: A Self-tuning Anomaly Detection Service
awd_abstract_narration:
Finding and understanding anomalous behavior in data is important in many applications. A large number of anomaly detection algorithms exist, and it can be difficult to determine which algorithm is best suited to a particular domain.  And once an algorithm is selected, users must tune many parameters manually to get the algorithm to perform well; this requires in-depth knowledge of the machine learning process and an understanding of the trade-offs among different algorithms to select the best performing approach.  To address these difficulties, this team develops a package that can test a range of unsupervised anomaly detection techniques on a dataset, explore options to identify best-fit, and classify anomalies with higher accuracy than manual tuning.

The project will automatically test a range of unsupervised anomaly techniques on a data set, extract knowledge from the combined detection results to reliably distinguish between anomalies and normal data, and use this knowledge as labels to train an anomaly classifier; the goal is to classify anomalies with an accuracy higher than what is achievable by thorough manual tuning. The approach can be applied across of a range of data types and domains. The resulting cyberinfrastructure provides tuning-free anomaly detection capabilities while making it easy to incorporate domain-specific requirements. It enables scientists and engineers having little experience with anomaly detection techniques to steer the anomaly detection process with domain expertise.  Evaluation of the unsupervised anomaly detection package will use data sets and partnerships with collaborators from the Massachusetts General Hospital/Harvard Medical School, Cyber Security research, and Signify (formerly Philips Lighting) to ensure that the utility and usability of the package is verified throughout the development process. 

This award by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by the NSF Division of Information and Intelligent Systems within the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Anomaly detection is vital in many scientific and engineering fields, from identifying new cyberattack signatures to detecting seizures in EEG medical time series datasets. Although numerous anomaly detection algorithms have been developed through research, effective anomaly detection remains challenging for domain experts due to the complexities involved in manual tuning. Experts must manually engineer the features to prepare data and determine which of the many algorithms is best suited to their specific domain. Moreover, they need to manually adjust multiple parameters to ensure optimal performance from the chosen algorithm. This is challenging because domain experts often lack a comprehensive understanding of the various detection algorithms and in-depth knowledge of the machine learning process. This project addresses this common problem by developing a robust, self-tuning anomaly detection cyber-infrastructure called STAND. It enables scientists and engineers with limited knowledge of anomaly detection techniques to use them effectively.

STAND uses a transformative approach to achieve self-tuning anomaly detection. It automatically tests a range of unsupervised anomaly techniques on a given dataset and extracts knowledge from the combined detection results to reliably distinguish between anomalies and normal data. It then uses this knowledge to learn an anomaly classifier that can classify anomalies more accurately than manual tuning alone. STAND is versatile, as it can be applied across various data types and domains. It includes components to help ingest and model common data types, such as time series, images, and tables. Additionally, it produces a domain-specific anomaly classifier ready for deployment. It is extensible, allowing developers to easily integrate new anomaly algorithms. Finally, it allows users to guide the anomaly detection process with domain expertise through feedback.

Broader Impact: The STAND project has broad societal and practical impact by making advanced anomaly detection accessible to domain experts with limited technical backgrounds, supporting applications in diverse fields such as cybersecurity, medical diagnostics, and material sciences. Its user-friendly, self-tuning approach democratizes anomaly detection, reducing barriers to technology use and enabling faster, more reliable anomaly detection that can be tailored to specific needs.

Intellectual Merit: The STAND project advances the field of anomaly detection through the creation of a versatile, self-tuning system that integrates a wide range of unsupervised anomaly detection methods. By automating algorithm selection and parameter tuning, STAND represents a novel and scalable solution that simplifies the detection process while enhancing accuracy, laying the groundwork for further innovation in automated anomaly detection systems.

Outcome: The STAND project successfully developed a robust, publicly accessible anomaly detection system that automates algorithm selection and parameter tuning, making anomaly detection more accessible to users across domains. Key outcomes include the release of a web-hosted prototype that simplifies access and usability, integration with the PyOD library to support over 50 outlier detection algorithms, and improvements in system efficiency through code refactoring and parallel processing. STAND’s dashboard allows users to interactively analyze and compare results, enhancing the tool's utility across use cases, including collaborations with the U.S. Army Research Lab and mental health research teams. The project also supported student development in research and professional skills, with dissemination of findings at major conferences and through open-source repositories.

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2024
Modified by: Samuel Madden
